en: Interview with Terry Williams, 2019-12-14

Interview with Terry Williams, former resident of Gatlinburg, Williams discusses the day of the fire and the surprise of how close it had approached his home. He recounts his evacuation and then his return, finding that his home had been destroyed. He also talks about the community and the sense of outreach that was constant throughout the aftermath. This is a representative quote from the interview: "[The wind] was just more violent. My fear at that point had nothing to do with fire, I thought trees were gonna come crashing down onto my home. It was that much more intense then I had ever heard before."

This is a representative quote from the interview: "[The wind] was just more violent. My fear at that point had nothing to do with fire, I thought trees were gonna come crashing down onto my home. It was that much more intense then I had ever heard before."

Interview with Terry Williams, 2019-12-14
Interview Questions
Can you tell us about how long you have been in Gatlinburg?
Why did you agree to participate in this?
Can you tell us when you first became aware of the fire?
Where were you when you became aware of the fire?
Did you have any suspicions that the fire would reach Gatlinburg?
When did you realize the severity of the fire?
Can you describe what was different about the wind that day?
Can you describe what the fire looked like?
This was about 8:15pm?
Can you describe the surreal feeling?
Did you leave with the police officer?
Did you evacuate through 321?
When you were sitting on 441 in Gatlinburg, could you see fire anywhere else?
Was there any fear in your mind when you were escaping?
Did you have any trouble in getting off of the mountain?
As you approach 321, you then head towards Pittman Center?
What was on fire as you were driving down 321?
So several people in Pittman Center joined together to further evacuate?
All the way to TN 32 was bumper to bumper traffic?
That was when you started to receive news reports?
After you were in Newport, how long was it until you could return to Pittman Center?
How far could you get into Gatlinburg before police stopped you?
What was your initial reaction when you saw the pictures of your destroyed home?
What was your initial reaction when you saw the pictures of your destroyed home?
So everything was gone?
Did you see any of your neighbors during your evacuation?
After losing everything, what was your first step?
Were you working at the time?
What was your first step getting back into Gatlinburg? You didnâ€™t rebuild?
Did you talk with your neighbors and friends about the fire?
How did the community of Gatlinburg respond to this?
When you talk with friends and neighbors, how do they contend with the disaster?
Do you think this fire could happen again?
Is there anything else that you would like to talk about?
